data.text: A Power Meter and a Fitness Tracker for a Gravel Bike?
Do you use a power meter on your gravel bike? Needed? Cheers!
On gravel there are more performance factors than on pavement. I just focus on the engine, using HRM and "feel" to set pace on long rides. If money was involved I would prob use a power meter.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: Another point in favor of HRM is that by occasionally comparing with frequent riding friends you can figure out who is having the better day, then work together to be sure the workout is good for everyone. Rider doing better gets to take more pulls.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: heart rate doesn‚Äôt work like that. Can vary a huge amount between 2 persons. A pm is the only way to compare and only if accounting for rider weight.
data.author: Rich Wachtel

data.text: True. I should clarify that HRM comparison only works if you have a lot of experience riding with same person and have figured out how your zones compare. The rider I had in mind has ridden maybe 20 centuries with me, and HRM comparison is very good at predicting how we‚Äôre doing.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: Yes. no. I only have one on my gravel bike to record data and satisfy my anxiety of incomplete data üò¢ Any training is done elsewhere
data.author: Fraser Kynaston

data.text: Necessary? No, but nice. Especially as you get onto rougher roads/trails, I find it harder to go on feel as you can be pushing out a lot of watts but be going frustratingly slow‚Ä¶helps me keep pacing at reasonable levels
data.author: Eric Vollmer

data.text: Useful on any bike. Necessary only if you want to maximize training, usually I do my power based intervals on my trainer because I ride 3 bikes depending on conditions. If money was no object I would have 5 bikes and 5 power meters. ü§£

Chris Hansen

data.text: Not necessary but a fun training toy. I‚Äôve been using a hrm for a while. I find heart rate to be a lagging indicator. By the time you spike too high it is difficult to recover on the climb. I did the expedo hack on a set of favero assiomo pedals. If you like to try to beat your Strava segment pr‚Äôs, power meters help a lot. You also learn how long you can reasonable sustain a given effort of a climb or zone 4-5 effort. It all depends if you are competitive with yourself and hope to improve your performance over past efforts. If you just ride for sport and are content with your efforts, power meters aren‚Äôt needed.
data.author: Kevin Pedersen

data.text: I only use a power on indoor Zwift rides. Outdoors I go by mix of feel and heart rate.
data.author: Stephen Brown

data.text: Absolutely, yes it‚Äôs needed, it‚Äôs the best way to train and to manage your effort. It‚Äôs the only way to get a objective feedback on your rides. Every other metric is subjective.
data.author: Jonathan Perez

data.text: doing the CyclingDiet program and want to be the more accurate possible with the training
data.author: Carlos Cortes

data.text: I can‚Äôt speak to weight management. A power meter will give better metrics than any other device
data.author: Jonathan Perez

data.text: I mean part of the program is to execute specific workouts and the app will use all data/metrics for progress evaluation
data.author: Carlos Cortes

data.text: avoid gimmicky power meters like the Velopod and the PowerCal strap. I prefer Stages. 4iiii is a good one that I‚Äôve used too. I also have a power tap hub that I‚Äôve used. It‚Äôs my 3rd favorite.

data.text: my legs give me plenty of objective feedback -they object every time I hit a hill. Maybe its because I've been riding for 40 years.

data.author: Brett Jensen

data.text: needed? No, of course not. You need tires, handlebars, and pedals. Gears and brakes? Optional. However a power meter is a great tool for training
data.author: Rob Beare

data.text: I have Quarqs on both. Unnecessary, but I‚Äôm a geek like that. They are handy for training/intervals. Also, I can keep power low on long rides easier. Or when working with less powerful riders, I can determine what power is hurting them and group dynamics. Very handy for me. But honestly, I use my HR to determine whether I need to back it down or work harder. So a PM is just like any other toy. Nice to have if you‚Äôve got the budget.

data.text: I like gadgets-toys, plus metrics/data, also do my best when training and review results

data.text: Not necessary. I used one for a couple of years, but got rid of it when hitting a number became my focus rather than just enjoying the ride. Now days I don't even use my computer most of the time unless I'm in a race.

I do track every ride, but the biggest measure of how good the ride was is the number of pictures I take along the way!
